citations.narrative:
The facility has several enclosures in need of repair to protect animals from injury and to contain the animals.
- A degu was found outside of its primary enclosure and inside of an enclosure housing nine pigeons and a Lady Amherst
pheasant.
- There is a large portion of underlying dig wire and side wire exposed along the front of the enclosure of both red fox
enclosures, creating large holes/gaps under the wire flooring. The dig wire is a 2” x 2” mesh, large enough for a leg or
paw to reach through.
- In the African Crested Porcupine enclosure, there are two layers of mesh under the enclosure floor to prevent animals
from digging and escaping. Inside of one shelter, the mesh has been completely dug up and broken apart, leaving large
portions of wire exposed and even a tall, sharp edge of wire protruding from the floor at least 12” up into the shelter.
Additionally, there is an area of tangled wire mesh sitting on the surface of the enclosure floor.
- One side of the hay rack in the Texas Doll Sheep enclosure has significant damage to the wire panel, exposing
numerous sharp edges of wire.
Having exposed wire mesh and sharp edges of wire in enclosures can lead to animals becoming injured or entrapped.
Additionally, animals that are not securely contained in their primary enclosures can become injured, lost, or killed by
outside predators. Correct by ensuring outdoor housing facilities are structurally sound and maintained in good repair to
protect the animals from injury and to contain the animals.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
n

narrative:
3.125(a)  Repeat
   
Facilities, general. 
The facility has several enclosures in need of repair to protect animals from injury and to contain the animals. 
 - A degu was found outside of its primary enclosure and inside of an enclosure housing nine pigeons and a Lady Amherst 
pheasant. 
 - There is a large portion of underlying dig wire and side wire exposed along the front of the enclosure of both red fox 
enclosures, creating large holes/gaps under the wire flooring. The dig wire is a 2” x 2” mesh, large enough for a leg or 
paw to reach through.  
 - In the African Crested Porcupine enclosure, there are two layers of mesh under the enclosure floor to prevent animals 
from digging and escaping. Inside of one shelter, the mesh has been completely dug up and broken apart, leaving large 
portions of wire exposed and even a tall, sharp edge of wire protruding from the floor at least 12” up into the shelter. 
Additionally, there is an area of tangled wire mesh sitting on the surface of the enclosure floor.  
 - One side of the hay rack in the Texas Doll Sheep enclosure has significant damage to the wire panel, exposing 
numerous sharp edges of wire.  
Having exposed wire mesh and sharp edges of wire in enclosures can lead to animals becoming injured or entrapped. 
Additionally, animals that are not securely contained in their primary enclosures can become injured, lost, or killed by 
outside predators. Correct by ensuring outdoor housing facilities are structurally sound and maintained in good repair to 
protect the animals from injury and to contain the animals. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee. 
 
 n
